CLVM-482741 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.67.162	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:20 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482732 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.56.90	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:33 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482723 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.60.222	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:32 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482717 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.208.154	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:12 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482709 
EOL/Obsolete Operating System: VMware ESXi 5.5 Detected 
2240 		172.21.209.27	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:09 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi 5.5 has been detected on the host. 
Support for VMware ESXi 5.5 ended on September 19, 2018.
QID Detection Logic (unauthenticated):
This QID reviews OS information from VMware API SOAP request.	Update to a supported version of ESXi. Refer to <a href="https://www.vmware.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMware</a> for information on obtaining the latest version.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482703 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.136	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:00 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482699 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.61.206	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:27 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)

CLVM-482658 
RPC Mountd Allows Remote Anonymous File System Root Mount 
2240 		172.21.209.101	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:22 	S2 (High) 	The host allows the file system root "/" to be remotely and anonymously mounted. Typically, the configuration file for the "rpc.mountd" daemon is "/etc/exports".	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

2240 	22 	172.21.67.100	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:19 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.

CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482638 
VMware ESXi 5.0.0 Patch Release ESXi500-201510001 Missing (KB2113684) 
2240 		172.21.63.137	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
The target is missing update ESXi500-201510001, which resolves the following security issues:
Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2120209" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi500-201510101-SG</a>
Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2120210" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi500-201510102-SG</a>
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2113684" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2113684</a> or <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2015-0007.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0007</a> or <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2016-0001.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2016-0001</a> for further details.	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 3021432 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2113684" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2113684</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://my.vmware.com/web/vmware/login" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0007: VMware ESXi 5.0.0</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482635 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.163	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:13 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482633 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.60.118	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:27 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.

CLVM-482627 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.67.154	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:05 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482621 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.56.73	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:10 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482563 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.129	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:50 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>

Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482549 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.67.160	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:24 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482547 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.61.207	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:07 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482542

for further details.	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESX 4.0 Build 989856 or the latest VMware ESX 4.0 build.

CLVM-482524 
Microsoft Windows Remote Desktop Protocol Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (MS12-020) 
2240 		172.21.52.40	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.27 02:11 	S1 (Urgent) 	The Remote Desktop feature in Windows enables access to all of the programs, resources and accessories on a user's computer from a second Windows-based computer.
A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way the Remote Desktop Protocol accesses an object in memory that has been improperly initialized or has been deleted (CVE-2012-0002).
A denial of service vulnerability exists in the way the Remote Desktop Protocol service processes packets. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could cause the target service to stop responding (CVE-2012-0152).
This security update is rated Critical for all supported releases of Microsoft Windows.
Note:
NLA or network layer authentication is a layer of security on top of RDP. If NLA is enabled then the vulnerability can be exploited remotely but will need credentials.
1. The authenticated check will determine presence of this vulnerability irrespective of the NLA setting.
2. The remote check can determine presence of this vulnerability only if NLA is disabled.
We encourage customers to patch irrespective of the NLA status.
Windows Embedded Systems:- For additional information regarding security updates for embedded systems, refer to the following MSDN blog(s):
<a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/embedded/archive/2012/03/26/march-2012-security-updates-for-xpe-sp3-and-standard-2009-are-now-on-ece.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">March 2012 Security Updates for XPe SP3 and Standard 2009 Are Now on ECE</a> (KB2621440)
<a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/embedded/archive/2012/04/24/april-2012-security-updates-are-live-on-ece-for-xpe-and-standard-2009.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">April 2012 Security Updates are Live on ECE for XPe and Standard 2009</a> (KB2621440)
Note: This vulnerability is applicable to versions of the software that are not listed in the official advisory.	Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=18a1fe48-1318-4b93-afad-206950bb1ae5" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MS12-020: Windows XP Service Pack 3</a>

	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482507 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.212	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:15 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482506 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.54.210	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:44 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482503 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.208.164	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:30 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482445 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.177	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:28 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

<a href="https://my.vmware.com/web/vmware/login" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0001: VMware ESXi 5.5.0</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482420 
VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG Missing (KB 2150882) 
2240 		172.21.60.231	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:20 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. A local user on the guest system can cause denial of service conditions on the guest system.
Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5.0	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267 or the latest VMware ESXi build.

CLVM-482419 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.67.151	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:14 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482416 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	10000 	172.21.209.13	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:19 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482407 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
1367 	22 	172.25.192.81	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:41 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482359 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.56.86	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:31 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482315 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.65	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:39 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482300

2240 		172.21.60.177	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:52 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESX Server abstracts server processor, memory, storage, and networking resources into multiple virtual machines to add management and reliability services to the core server product.

CLVM-482296 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.67.101	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:26 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:

CLVM-482278 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.56.92	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:10 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482255 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.62.139	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482254 
Writeable Root Directory on FTP Server 
2240 	21 	172.21.52.40	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.27 02:11 	S1 (Urgent) 	The FTP server has a world writeable root directory. The root directory of your FTP server can therefore be written-to by any user.	Disable write access for unauthorized users in the root directory of the FTP server.
For UNIX:
$ chmod o-w path/to/ftp/root/directory
For Microsoft IIS 6:
1. Click Start, point to Administrative Tools, and then click Internet Information Services (IIS).
2. In IIS Manager, expand the local computer, expand the FTP Sites folder, right-click the FTP site in question, and click Properties.
3. Click the Home Directory tab and deselect the Write checkbox; click OK.
4. For advanced permissions, refer to step 2 and click Permissions instead of Properties; then click Advanced Permissions.
For other versions of IIS, please refer to the Microsoft website.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482244 
VMware ESX 4.0 Third Party Updates for Service Console (VMSA-2010-0013) 
2240 		172.21.60.177	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:52 	S2 (High) 	Vmware ESX 4.0 released updates for Service Console to resolve the following vulnerabilities:
Buffer overflow in cpio 2.6-8.FC4 on 64-bit platforms, when creating a cpio archive, allows local users to cause a denial of service (crash) and possibly execute arbitrary code via a file whose size is represented by more than 8 digits. 
Heap-based buffer overflow in the rmt_read__ function in lib/rtapelib.c in the rmt client functionality in GNU tar before 1.23 and GNU cpio before 2.11 allows remote rmt servers to cause a denial of service (memory corruption) or possibly execute arbitrary code by sending more data than was requested, related to archive filenames that contain a : (colon) character. 
Buffer overflow in the SMB1 packet chaining implementation in the chain_reply function in process.c in smbd in Samba 3.0.x before 3.3.13 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory corruption and daemon crash) or possibly execute arbitrary code via a crafted field in a packet. 
The kg_accept_krb5 function in krb5/accept_sec_context.c in the GSS-API library in MIT Kerberos 5 through 1.7.1 and 1.8 before 1.8.2, as used in kadmind and other applications, does not properly check for invalid GSS-API tokens, which allows remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service (NULL pointer dereference and daemon crash) via an AP-REQ message in which the authenticator's checksum field is missing. 
The Safe module before 2.25 for Perl allows context-dependent attackers to bypass intended Safe::reval and Safe::rdo access restrictions, and inject and execute arbitrary code, via vectors involving implicitly called methods and implicitly blessed objects, as demonstrated by the DESTROY and AUTOLOAD methods, related to "automagic methods." 
The Safe module 2.26, and certain earlier versions, for Perl, as used in PostgreSQL 7.4 before 7.4.29, 8.0 before 8.0.25, 8.1 before 8.1.21, 8.2 before 8.2.17, 8.3 before 8.3.11, 8.4 before 8.4.4, and 9.0 Beta before 9.0 Beta 2, allows context-dependent attackers to bypass intended Safe::reval and Safe::rdo access restrictions, and inject and execute arbitrary code, via vectors involving subroutine references and delayed execution.	To resolve this vulnerability, upgrade to the latest packages. Refer to VMware security advisory <a href="http://www.wmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2010-0013.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2010-0013</a> to address this issue and obtain patch details.

CLVM-482240 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.67.161	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:12 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)

CLVM-482185 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.164	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:30 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74

CLVM-482184 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.131	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:57 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482169 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.161	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:12 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482157 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.46	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:12 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)

CLVM-482155 
WordPress Prior to 4.9.1 Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	80 	172.21.52.10	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:03 	S2 (High) 	WordPress is an open source blogging tool and content management system based on PHP and MySQL. It has many features including a plug-in architecture and a template system.
WordPress contains the following vulnerabilities:
CVE-2017-17091: The implemented wp-admin/user-new.php source file sets the newbloguser key to a string that can be directly derived from the user ID, which allows remote attackers to bypass intended access restrictions by entering this string. 
CVE-2017-17092: The implemented wp-includes/functions.php source file does not require the unfiltered_html capability for upload of .js files, which might allow remote attackers to conduct XSS attacks via a crafted file.
CVE-2017-17093: The implemented wp-includes/general-template.php source file does not properly restrict the lang attribute of an HTML element, which might allow attackers to conduct XSS attacks via the language setting of a site. 
CVE-2017-17094: The implemented wp-includes/feed.php source file does not properly restrict enclosures in RSS and Atom fields, which might allow attackers to conduct XSS attacks via a crafted URL. 
Affected Versions:
WordPress prior to 4.9.1
QID Detection Logic:
This QID depends on BlindElephant engine to detect the version of the WordPress installation as active attacks could potentially harm live installations.	Customers are advised to install <a href="https://wordpress.org/download/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">WordPress 4.9.1</a> or later versions to remediate the vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://wordpress.org/download/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">WordPress 4.9.1 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482151 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.67.164	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:27 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482125 
RPC Mountd Allows Remote Anonymous File System Root Mount 
2240 		172.21.60.95	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:46 	S2 (High) 	The host allows the file system root "/" to be remotely and anonymously mounted.	Configure the host's "mount" daemon to disallow root and other mount points with sensitive content that should not be publically accessible. Typically, the configuration file for the "rpc.mountd" daemon is "/etc/exports".	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482124 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.154	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.15 22:34 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.

VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-Update03: Complete Update 3 Missing (KB2110231) 
2240 		172.21.67.160	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:24 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product.

Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2110247" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi550-201509101-SG</a>
Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2116271" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi550-201509102-SG</a>
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2110231" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2110231</a> or <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2015-0007.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0007</a> for further details.	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 3029944 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2110231" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2110231</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://my.vmware.com/web/vmware/login" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0007: VMware ESXi 5.5.0</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482098 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.56.94	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:46 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482087 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.68	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:57 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482079 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.147	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:41 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482067 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.91	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:15 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-482035 
VMware Third Party Component Updates for ESX 4.x (VMSA-2011-0013) 
2240 		172.21.60.177	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:52 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware third party component updates for VMware ESX 4.x resolved several issues.
ESX third party update for Service Console openssl RPM. The Service Console openssl RPM is updated to openssl-0.9.8e.12.el5_5.7 resolving two security issues.
ESX third party update for Service Console libuser RPM. The Service Console libuser RPM is updated to version 0.54.7-2.1.el5_5.2 to resolve a security issue.
ESX third party update for Service Console nss and nspr RPMs. The Service Console Network Security Services (NSS) and Netscape Portable Runtime (NSPR) libraries are updated to nspr-4.8.6-1 and nss-3.12.8-4 resolving multiple security issues.
vCenter Server and ESX, Oracle (Sun) JRE update 1.6.0_24. Oracle (Sun) JRE is updated to version 1.6.0_24, which addresses multiple security issues that existed in earlier releases of Oracle (Sun) JRE.
Integer overflow in VMware third party component sfcb. This release resolves an integer overflow issue present in the third party library SFCB when the httpMaxContentLength has been changed from its default value to 0 in in /etc/sfcb/sfcb.cfg. The integer overflow could allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (heap memory corruption) or possibly execute arbitrary code via a large integer in the Content-Length HTTP header.
Affected Versions:
ESX 4.1 without patches ESX410-201110201-SG, ESX410-201110204-SG, ESX410-201110206-SG and ESX410-201110214-SG.
ESX 4.0 without patch ESX400-201111201-SG.	The vendor has released patches to resolve this issue. Refer to VMware Security Advisory <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2011-0013.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2011-0013</a> to obtain additional details about the vulnerability.
