CLVM-482016 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.60.209	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.26 22:56 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482007 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.123	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:48 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-482002 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.216	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:33 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)

2240 	22 	172.21.58.103	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:27 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74

This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.

This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service. CLVM-481985 
VMware ESXi 6.5 Patch Release ESXi650-201712103-SG,ESXi650-201712101-SG Missing (KB 2151102)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.209.110	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:54 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS) (CVE-2017-4940)
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.)(CVE-2017-5753, CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 6.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 7273056 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2151102" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2151102</a> for updates and build information.

WordPress versions prior to 4.7.2 contain the following unauthorized bypass, SQL injection, cross-site scripting vulnerabilities:
CVE-2017-5610: The user interface for assigning taxonomy terms in Press This is shown to users who do not have permissions to use it. 
CVE-2017-5611: WP_Query is vulnerable to a SQL injection (SQLi) when passing unsafe data. WordPress core is not directly vulnerable to this issue
CVE-2017-5612: A cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability was discovered in the posts list table.
CVE-2017-1001000: A privilege escalation vulnerability in Wordpress that allows unauthenticated users to inject content in posts.
Affected Versions:

CLVM-481959 
Null Authentication VNC Server Access 
2240 	5901 	172.21.67.48	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:52 	S1 (Urgent) 	VNC (Virtual Network Computing) is similar to Xwindows in that it is a remote, graphical interface. It is freely available from multiple vendors (for example AT&T Cambridge).
To create a session with VNC server, a primitive sort of authentication is implemented. There is an option to not use authentication at all, in which case anyone is allowed to connect to the VNC server.
An example of such default configuration is ClumpOS.
ClumpOS is a CD-based Linux and Mosix distribution that is maintained and distributed by the Mosix project. ClumpOS does not prompt a user to set a password for VNC when installed. Instead, ClumpOS leaves the default password for VNC blank, which allows remote root access to the system.	As a possible workaround, manually set a VNC password or remove the VNC server (if not needed).	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481958 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.124	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:45 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.

CLVM-481939 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.67.162	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:20 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build.

CLVM-481921 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.58.103	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:27 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481917 
VMWare ESXi 5.0.0 Patch Release ESXi500-201112001 Missing (KB2007680)

for further details.	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 515841 or the latest VMware ESXi build.

CLVM-481915 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.54.210	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.15 20:46 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481909 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.50	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:33 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481907 
SQL Files Present on Anonymous FTP Server Vulnerability 
2240 	21 	172.21.52.40	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:39 	S1 (Urgent) 	The anonymous FTP server hosts one or more SQL files that may contain sensitive information, such as logins and passwords, database tables, and records.	Removes files with the .sql extension.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481888 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.58.194	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:13 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481869 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.209.27	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:09 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481868 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.67.164	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:27 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481859 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.52.10	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:03 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481856 
EOL/Obsolete Operating System: VMware ESXi 5.5 Detected 
2240 		172.21.67.160	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:24 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi 5.5 has been detected on the host. 
Support for VMware ESXi 5.5 ended on September 19, 2018.
QID Detection Logic (unauthenticated):
This QID reviews OS information from VMware API SOAP request.	Update to a supported version of ESXi. Refer to <a href="https://www.vmware.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMware</a> for information on obtaining the latest version.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.56.122	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:14 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing.

If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>

Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.

Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9).

CLVM-481851 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.59.134	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:34 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481846 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.63.132	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:06 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481843

CLVM-481818 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.67.160	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:24 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.113	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:10 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing.

Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481783 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.67.163	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:13 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481773 
EOL/Obsolete Software: Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.x Detected 
2240 		172.21.50.89	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	Microsoft Internet Information Services Web Server 6.x was detected on the target host.
Microsoft ended support for IIS 6.0 on July 14, 2015 and provides no further support for this application.
Note: IIS 6.0 servers are being exploited with the "EXPLODINGCAN" exploit.
This information comes from the Shadow Brokers' "Equation Group" data dump and security researchers Zhiniang Peng and Chen Wu.	Microsoft IIS 6.0 is End of Life and Microsoft provides no support.
IIS 6.0 servers are being exploited with the "EXPLODINGCAN" exploit.
This information comes from the Shadow Brokers' "Equation Group" data dump and security researchers Zhiniang Peng and Chen Wu.
Upgrade to the latest version of Microsoft IIS. 
Refer to <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/web/platform/server.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow"> Microsoft/web </a> for more details.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481768 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
1367 		172.25.192.81	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:41 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481751 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.28	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:12 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481745 
RPC Mountd Allows Remote Anonymous File System Root Mount 
2240 		172.21.60.96	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:06 	S2 (High) 	The host allows the file system root "/" to be remotely and anonymously mounted.	Configure the host's "mount" daemon to disallow root and other mount points with sensitive content that should not be publically accessible. Typically, the configuration file for the "rpc.mountd" daemon is "/etc/exports".	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 6.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481739 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.205	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:08 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481730 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.179	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481729 
VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-Update03: Complete Update 3 Missing (KB2110231)

CLVM-481691 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.137	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:10 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.

Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. CLVM-481653 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.60.208	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.22 07:38 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481637 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.208.228	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:51 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481616 
VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG Missing (KB 2150882) 
2240 		172.21.67.160	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:24 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. A local user on the guest system can cause denial of service conditions on the guest system.
Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5.0	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2150876" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:

CLVM-481615 
VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-Update03: Complete Update 3 Missing (KB2110231)

The target is missing update ESXi550-Update03, which resolves the following security issues:

To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 3029944 or the latest VMware ESXi build.

CLVM-481613 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.95	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:59 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481567 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.208.227	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:01 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481547 
WordPress Prior to 5.0.1 Multiple Security Vulnerability 
2240 	80 	172.21.52.10	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:03 	S2 (High) 	WordPress is software designed for everyone, emphasizing accessibility, performance, security, and ease of use>
WordPress 5.0.1 is now available. This is a security release for all versions since WordPress 3.7.
WordPress 5.0.1 fixes Flaws like:
PHP unserialization 
Cross-site scripting (XSS): allow an attacker to bypass MIME verification by uploading specially-crafted files on Apache-hosted sites.
Affected Versions:
WordPress version from 3.7 to 5.0.0
QID Detection Logic:
This unauthenticated QID detects vulnerable installations based on the BlindElephant fingerprinting engine.	Refer to WordPress security advisory <a href="https://wordpress.org/news/2018/12/wordpress-5-0-1-security-release/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">WordPress</a> to address this issue and obtain further details.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://wordpress.org/news/2018/12/wordpress-5-0-1-security-release/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">WordPress</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481543 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.67.151	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:14 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

VMware ESXi 5.1.0 Patch Release ESXi510-201510401 Missing (KB2114860) 
2240 		172.21.209.29	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:03 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product.

Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2114875" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi510-201510101-SG</a>
Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2126488" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi510-201510102-SG</a>
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2114860" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2114860</a>, <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2015-0007.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0007</a> or <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2016-0001.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2016-0001</a> for further details.	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 3021178 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2114860" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2114860</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://my.vmware.com/web/vmware/login" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0007: VMware ESXi 5.1.0</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481526 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.164	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:30 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481522 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.61.208	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:06 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481514

2240 		172.21.62.140	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:39 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product.

Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2126488" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi510-201510102-SG</a>
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2114860" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2114860</a>, <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2015-0007.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0007</a> or <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2016-0001.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2016-0001</a> for further details. CLVM-481507 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.56.90	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:33 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481485 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.67.161	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:12 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481452 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.141	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:25 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481449 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.67.190	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:07 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481446 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
1367 	22 	172.25.192.81	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:41 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481425 
VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-Update03: Complete Update 3 Missing (KB2110231) 
2240 		172.21.56.94	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:46 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
The target is missing update ESXi550-Update03, which resolves the following security issues:
Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2110247" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi550-201509101-SG</a>
Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2116271" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi550-201509102-SG</a>

To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 3029944 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2110231" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2110231</a> for updates and build information.

CLVM-481413 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.218	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:56 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.

CLVM-481387 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.135	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:08 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481385 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.71	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:58 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)

Affected Versions

If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>

CLVM-481362 
Oracle MySQL October 2018 Critical Patch Update (CPUOCT2018)

CLVM-481336 
VMware ESXi 6.5 Patch Release ESXi650-201712103-SG,ESXi650-201712101-SG Missing (KB 2151102)(Spectre) 
2240 		172.21.209.112	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:15 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS) (CVE-2017-4940)
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.)(CVE-2017-5753, CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 6.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 7273056 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2151102" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2151102</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 6.5</a>
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2018-0002.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2018-0002: VMware ESXi 6.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481334 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.68	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:57 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481330 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.208.63	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:03 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing.
