CLVM-481327 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.67.49	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:17 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481321 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.56.86	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481313

2240 		172.21.63.137	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product.

for further details.	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 721882 or the latest VMware ESXi build.

CLVM-481278 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.54.216	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:45 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.

Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. CLVM-481275 
Microsoft Windows Remote Desktop Protocol Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (MS12-020) 
2240 		172.21.50.89	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	The Remote Desktop feature in Windows enables access to all of the programs, resources and accessories on a user's computer from a second Windows-based computer.
A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way the Remote Desktop Protocol accesses an object in memory that has been improperly initialized or has been deleted (CVE-2012-0002).
A denial of service vulnerability exists in the way the Remote Desktop Protocol service processes packets. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could cause the target service to stop responding (CVE-2012-0152).
This security update is rated Critical for all supported releases of Microsoft Windows.
Note:
NLA or network layer authentication is a layer of security on top of RDP. If NLA is enabled then the vulnerability can be exploited remotely but will need credentials.
1. The authenticated check will determine presence of this vulnerability irrespective of the NLA setting.
2. The remote check can determine presence of this vulnerability only if NLA is disabled.
We encourage customers to patch irrespective of the NLA status.
Windows Embedded Systems:- For additional information regarding security updates for embedded systems, refer to the following MSDN blog(s):
<a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/embedded/archive/2012/03/26/march-2012-security-updates-for-xpe-sp3-and-standard-2009-are-now-on-ece.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">March 2012 Security Updates for XPe SP3 and Standard 2009 Are Now on ECE</a> (KB2621440)
<a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/embedded/archive/2012/04/24/april-2012-security-updates-are-live-on-ece-for-xpe-and-standard-2009.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">April 2012 Security Updates are Live on ECE for XPe and Standard 2009</a> (KB2621440)
Note: This vulnerability is applicable to versions of the software that are not listed in the official advisory.	Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=18a1fe48-1318-4b93-afad-206950bb1ae5" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MS12-020: Windows XP Service Pack 3</a>
<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=eccf865d-399a-4862-b26f-f35580419875" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MS12-020: Windows XP Professional x64 Edition Service Pack 2</a>
<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=b69b4b9b-c0a1-4c1e-b081-8529eaf1536a" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MS12-020: Windows Server 2003 Service Pack 2</a>
<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=8081e67f-288c-4714-bff8-e0ff9777692f" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MS12-020: Windows Server 2003 x64 Edition Service Pack 2</a>
<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=521baa02-5d7a-4cba-8a1a-2af1b6e4cbe4" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MS12-020: Windows Server 2003 with SP2 for Itanium-based Systems</a>
<a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=39abdf7b-ea9d-4b95-a28d-4140374d531d" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MS12-020: Windows Vista Service Pack 2</a>

CLVM-481270 
QNAP QTS Multiple Vulnerabilties (NAS-201811-22) 
2240 	443 	172.21.59.142	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:38 	S1 (Urgent) 	QNAP QTS is a advanced Turbo NAS Operating System. Based on Linux, QTS is designed to deliver high-performance applications and services fulfilling your needs in file sharing, storage management, backup, virtual environments, multimedia, surveillance and more.
QNAP QTS is prone to following vulnerabilities.
CVE-2018-14746: If exploited, this vulnerability could allow remote attackers to run arbitrary commands on the NAS.
CVE-2018-14747: If exploited, this vulnerability could allow remote attackers to crash the NAS media server.
CVE-2018-14748: If exploited, this vulnerability could allow remote attackers to power off the NAS.
CVE-2018-14749: If exploited, this buffer overflow vulnerability could have unspecified impact on the NAS.
Affected Versions:
QTS 4.3.5: build 20181013 and earlier versions
QTS 4.3.4: build 20181008 and earlier versions
QTS 4.3.3: build 20180829 and earlier versions
QTS 4.2.6: build 20180829 and earlier versions
QID Detection Logic (unauthenticated):
The QID sends a GET /cgi-bin/authLogin.cgi request to retrieve the version of QTS running on the remote target.	Customers are advised to upgrade to the latet version of the software. Refer to the following link for further details:
<a href="https://www.qnap.com/zh-tw/security-advisory/nas-201811-22" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">NAS-201811-22</a>
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.qnap.com/zh-tw/security-advisory/nas-201811-22" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">NAS-201811-22</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481261 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.195	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:05 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-201501001 Missing (KB2099265) 
2240 		172.21.209.27	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:09 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product.

CLVM-481251 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	172.21.208.226	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:34 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481240 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.210	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 15:34 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481239

CLVM-481236 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
1367 		172.25.192.143	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:59 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481208 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.209.211	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:39 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481186 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		172.21.60.207	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:52 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-481179 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.61.199	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 10:50 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-481158 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	172.21.52.14	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 11:03 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

2240 	22 	172.21.208.162	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 14:10 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.

Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library.

Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.

Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74

CLVM-481151 
Microsoft Windows Remote Desktop Protocol Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (MS12-020) 
2240 		172.21.50.90	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 12:19 	S1 (Urgent) 	The Remote Desktop feature in Windows enables access to all of the programs, resources and accessories on a user's computer from a second Windows-based computer.
A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way the Remote Desktop Protocol accesses an object in memory that has been improperly initialized or has been deleted (CVE-2012-0002).
A denial of service vulnerability exists in the way the Remote Desktop Protocol service processes packets. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could cause the target service to stop responding (CVE-2012-0152).
This security update is rated Critical for all supported releases of Microsoft Windows.
Note:
NLA or network layer authentication is a layer of security on top of RDP. If NLA is enabled then the vulnerability can be exploited remotely but will need credentials.
1. The authenticated check will determine presence of this vulnerability irrespective of the NLA setting.
2. The remote check can determine presence of this vulnerability only if NLA is disabled.
We encourage customers to patch irrespective of the NLA status.
Windows Embedded Systems:- For additional information regarding security updates for embedded systems, refer to the following MSDN blog(s):
<a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/embedded/archive/2012/03/26/march-2012-security-updates-for-xpe-sp3-and-standard-2009-are-now-on-ece.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">March 2012 Security Updates for XPe SP3 and Standard 2009 Are Now on ECE</a> (KB2621440)
<a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/embedded/archive/2012/04/24/april-2012-security-updates-are-live-on-ece-for-xpe-and-standard-2009.aspx" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">April 2012 Security Updates are Live on ECE for XPe and Standard 2009</a> (KB2621440)
Note: This vulnerability is applicable to versions of the software that are not listed in the official advisory.	Patch:

CLVM-481150 
Oracle MySQL October 2018 Critical Patch Update (CPUOCT2018)

CLVM-481149 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	172.21.63.132	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.15 18:55 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

for further details.	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 1022489 or the latest VMware ESXi build.

CLVM-481121 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	172.21.67.178	2019.Feb.16 	2019.Feb.21 13:02 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-478140 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	171.68.173.253	2019.Feb.14 	2019.Feb.19 14:29 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-475788 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
1367 		172.25.195.130	2019.Feb.09 	2019.Feb.21 15:37 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.

CLVM-475259 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.254.11	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 00:02 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:

<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-475233 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.255.45	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.08 00:00 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-475225 
VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG Missing (KB 2150882) 
2240 		10.29.255.151	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 02:14 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. A local user on the guest system can cause denial of service conditions on the guest system.
Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5.0	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267 or the latest VMware ESXi build.

CLVM-475199 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	5432 	10.29.255.252	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 05:34 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-475140 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		10.29.255.150	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 07:52 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-475113 
VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-Update03: Complete Update 3 Missing (KB2110231)

CLVM-475106 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.252.240	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 00:14 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-475066 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
1367 	22 	172.25.195.58	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.15 23:25 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-475061 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.254.103	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 23:58 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474973 
OpenSSL Memory Leak Vulnerability (Heartbleed Bug) 
2240 	443 	10.29.255.150	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 07:52 	S1 (Urgent) 	OpenSSL is a toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer Security (TLS v1) protocols as well as a full-strength general purpose cryptography library. For more details about the detection please refer to the Qualys community article <a href="https://community.qualys.com/blogs/qualys-tech/2014/04/09/heartbleed-detection-update" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">heartbleed-detection-update</a>.
OpenSSL is exposed to a security vulnerability due to a missing bounds check in the handling of the TLS heartbeat extension.
Affected Versions:
OpenSSL 1.0.1f, 1.0.1e, 1.0.1d, 1.0.1c, 1.0.1b, 1.0.1a, 1.0.1
PLEASE NOTE:
This QID will be reported as possible vulnerability (YELLOW) if it was triggered because the target host has a vulnerable OpenSSL banner.
This QID will be reports as confirmed vulnerability (RED) if the target responds to the SSL heartbeat request in a vulnerable fashion (irrespective of the OpenSSL banner).	Update to Version 1.0.1g to resolve this issue. The latest version is available for download from<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL Web site</a>.
Workaround:
	Recompile OpenSSL with the handshake removed from the code by compile time option -DOPENSSL_NO_HEARTBEATS. 
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-1.0.1g.tar.gz" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSL 1.0.1g</a>
Virtual Patches:
<a href="http://www.trendmicro.com/vulnerabilitycontrols" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Trend Micro Virtual Patching</a>
Virtual Patch #1006012: 1006012 - Identified Suspicious OpenSSL TLS/DTLS Heartbeat Request	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474970 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.254.6	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 00:21 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474967 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		10.29.255.151	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 02:14 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474848 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.254.82	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 00:02 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-474761 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
1367 	2222 	172.25.195.58	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.15 23:25 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-474602 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.254.6	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 00:21 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-474544 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.252.238	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 00:14 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474495

2240 		10.29.254.41	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 23:54 	S1 (Urgent) 	VMware ESXi 5.5 has been detected on the host. 
Support for VMware ESXi 5.5 ended on September 19, 2018.
QID Detection Logic (unauthenticated):
This QID reviews OS information from VMware API SOAP request.	Update to a supported version of ESXi. Refer to <a href="https://www.vmware.com/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMware</a> for information on obtaining the latest version.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-474441 
VMware ESXi 6.5 Patch Release ESXi650-201712103-SG,ESXi650-201712101-SG Missing (KB 2151102)(Spectre) 
2240 		10.29.254.49	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 00:26 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS) (CVE-2017-4940)
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.)(CVE-2017-5753, CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 6.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 7273056 or the latest VMware ESXi build.

CLVM-474418 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.254.21	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 00:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-474355 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		10.29.254.41	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 23:54 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.

CLVM-474328 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	10.29.255.158	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.22 07:42 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-474171 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.204.200	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 20:56 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-474104 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.204.204	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 21:08 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474092 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.204.206	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 21:31 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>

Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474085 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.204.202	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 19:30 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474067 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.204.205	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 19:14 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-474055 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.204.202	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 19:30 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-473946 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	10.29.209.6	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.07 20:26 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-473940 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.204.203	2019.Feb.08 	2019.Feb.21 21:58 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
