CLVM-460855 
Null Session/Password NetBIOS Access 
1367 		10.22.175.140	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 17:21 	S1 (Urgent) 	Unauthorized users can connect to this NetBIOS service without a password.	Null NetBIOS sessions can be disabled using the following methods:
Windows NT: 
1. Set the following registry key: 
HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa
Name: RestrictAnonymous
Type: REG_DWORD Value: 1
2. Restart your computer.
Windows 2000:
1. Start "Control Panel->Administrative Tools->Local Security Policy".
2. Open "Local Policies-->Security Options".
3. Make sure "Additional restrictions of anonymous connections" is set to
"No access without explicit anonymous permissions". 
4. Restart your computer.
Windows XP/2003: 
1. Start "Control Panel->Administrative Tools->Local Security Policy".
2. Open "Local Policies-->Security Options".
3. Make sure the following two policies are enabled:
•	Network Access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts 
•	Network Access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares
4. Disable Network Access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users.
5. Restart your computer. 
The above settings have no impact on domain controllers. If this vulnerability was discovered on a domain controller, please note that some of the recommended settings may not have any effect. Read the Microsoft article <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/kb/257988/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Description of Dcpromo Permissions Choices</a> for more information regarding Pre-Windows 2000 Compatible Access. Please read the Microsoft documents called <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;246261" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">How to Use the RestrictAnonymous Registry Value</a> for more information.
Samba: 
Make the following settings in smb.conf:
•	set "security" to "user" or "domain" or "server" as per your requirements. 
•	set "map_to_guest" to "Never" 
SECURITY = USER
This is the default security setting in Samba 2.2. With user-level security a client must first "log=on" with a valid username and password (which can be mapped using the username map parameter). Encrypted passwords can also be used in this security mode. Parameters such as user and guest only if set are then applied and may change the UNIX user to use on this connection, but only after the user has been successfully authenticated.
SECURITY = SERVER
In this mode Samba will try to validate the username/password by passing it to another SMB server, such as an NT box. If this fails it will revert to security = user, but note that if encrypted passwords have been negotiated then Samba cannot revert back to checking the UNIX password file, it must have a valid smbpasswd file to check users against. See the documentation file in the docs/ directory ENCRYPTION.txt for details on how to set this up.
SECURITY = DOMAIN
This mode will only work correctly if smbpasswd(8) has been used to add this machine into a Windows NT Domain. It expects the encrypted passwords parameter to be set to true. In this mode Samba will try to validate the username/password by passing it to a Windows NT Primary or Backup Domain Controller, in exactly the same way that a Windows NT Server would do.
•	Also add "restrict anonymous = 2" to the "[global]" configuration section.
Note:Setting this parameter in Samba versions prior to 4 may impact Samba's ability to service Windows 9x clients, act as a Domain Controller or serve as the Master Browser. 
For Windows Server 2008, please refer to <a href="http://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/winservergen/thread/841523db-8c4b-43a0-9f28-be7270f92e2b" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Disable Server 2008 Null Sessions</a>.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460851 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.213.194	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 17:08 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460850 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.207.66	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 21:26 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460849

CLVM-460844 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
1367 	22 	10.22.47.245	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.28 07:04 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460838 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	10.29.192.124	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 16:53 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460818 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.207.29	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 21:33 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460817 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.252.227	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.22 00:44 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):

QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):

CLVM-460811 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.211.38	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 15:38 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460809

An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)

CLVM-460796 
Null Authentication VNC Server Access 
1367 	5900 	10.22.168.64	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 15:42 	S1 (Urgent) 	VNC (Virtual Network Computing) is similar to Xwindows in that it is a remote, graphical interface. It is freely available from multiple vendors (for example AT&T Cambridge).
To create a session with VNC server, a primitive sort of authentication is implemented. There is an option to not use authentication at all, in which case anyone is allowed to connect to the VNC server.
An example of such default configuration is ClumpOS.
ClumpOS is a CD-based Linux and Mosix distribution that is maintained and distributed by the Mosix project. ClumpOS does not prompt a user to set a password for VNC when installed. Instead, ClumpOS leaves the default password for VNC blank, which allows remote root access to the system.	As a possible workaround, manually set a VNC password or remove the VNC server (if not needed).	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460793 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.192.39	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 18:42 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.

CLVM-460792 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.212.204	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 16:15 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460788 
VMware ESXi 5.5.0 Patch Release ESXi550-201501001 Missing (KB2099265) 
2240 		10.29.192.69	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 18:45 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
The target is missing update ESXi550-201501001, which resolves the following security issue:
Bulletin ID <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2099273" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">ESXi550-201501101-SG</a>
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2099265" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2099265</a> or <a href="http://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2015-0001.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0001</a> for further details.	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 2352327 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="http://kb.vmware.com/selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&externalId=2099265" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB2099265</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://my.vmware.com/web/vmware/login" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2015-0001: VMware ESXi 5.5.0</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460781 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.198.98	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 21:26 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460780 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.207.9	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 21:42 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460779 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
1367 	22 	10.22.175.91	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 18:13 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460757 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.212.205	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 19:02 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460737 
Apache Tomcat JK Web Server Connector Path Traversal Information Disclosure Vulnerability 
2240 	80 	10.29.194.102	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 20:29 	S2 (High) 	The Apache Web Server (httpd) specific code that normalised the requested path before matching it to the URI-worker map in Apache Tomcat JK (mod_jk) Connector did not handle some edge cases correctly.
If only a sub-set of the URLs supported by Tomcat were exposed via httpd, then it was possible for a specially constructed request to expose application functionality through the reverse proxy that was not intended for clients accessing the application via the reverse proxy.
It was also possible in some configurations for a specially constructed request to bypass the access controls configured in httpd.
It is vulnerable only if jkstatus is present with specific configurations in the server.
Affected Versions:
Apache Tomcat JK (mod_jk) Connector 1.2.0 to 1.2.44
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
It sends a GET request to serverIP/jkstatus; to check if target is vulnerable.	The vendor has advised to upgrade to Apache Tomcat JK ISAPI Connector to version 1.2.46 or later, which is available for download from <a href="https://tomcat.apache.org/download-connectors.cgi" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Apache Tomcat jk connector</a> Web site.
Workaround:
The vendor has advised to use alternative measures (e.g. the remote address filter) to restrict access to trusted users.
For more information please visit <a href="https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/6d564bb0ab73d6b3efdd1d6b1c075d1a2c84ecd84a4159d6122529ad@%3Cannounce.tomcat.apache.org%3E" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">here</a>.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="http://tomcat.apache.org/security-jk.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Apache Tomcat JK</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460736 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.209.148	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 19:54 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460735 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.206.82	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 15:42 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460730 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.199.9	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 16:01 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460723 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	10.29.192.2	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 20:47 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460717 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.193.151	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 17:07 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460712 
Cisco Catalyst 3500 XL Remote Arbitrary Command Execution Vulnerability 
1367 	80 	10.22.175.89	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 21:41 	S1 (Urgent) 	Cisco Catalyst 3500 XL is a high-speed switch implemented in local area networks. 
A vulnerability exists in the Web server configuration interface allowing anonymous unauthorized users to execute commands. HTTP requests that contain /exec and a known filename will reveal the contents of the file specified. In addition to disclosing the contents of files, this vulnerability could enable unauthorized users to execute arbitrary code.	A possible workaround involves disabling the Web configuration interface. Otherwise, contact CISCO for a patch. For more information, visit 
<a target="_blank" href="http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/cc/pd/si/casi/ca3500xl/index.shtml" rel="nofollow">Cisco's Catalyst 3500 Product Page</a>.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460702 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	10.29.254.254	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.22 00:15 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.194.3	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 16:12 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460690 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	10.29.253.254	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.22 00:26 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460687 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.205.180	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 21:14 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460686 
Cisco Router/Switch Default Password Vulnerability 
2240 	80 	10.29.193.161	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 16:24 	S1 (Urgent) 	Some Cisco routers/switches come with a default NULL password or unset password. If the password is not changed, remote users can access sensitive information about the device. Also, it's possible for configuration changes to be made, leading to a full compromise.	Please change your router/switch password immediately.
Check <a href="http://www.cisco.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Cisco's Web site</a> for further information.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460679 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.207.115	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 19:41 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

1367 		10.22.47.245	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.28 07:04 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460673 
VMware ESXi 5.5 Patch Release ESXi550-201709101-SG, ESXi550-201709102-SG Missing (KB 2150882)(Spectre) 
2240 		10.29.192.57	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 16:32 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
A vulnerability was reported in VMware ESXi. The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS).
Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.) (CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 5.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 6480267or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2150882?r=2&Quarterback.validateRoute=1&KM_Utility.getArticleData=1&KM_Utility.getGUser=1&KM_Utility.getArticleLanguage=1&KM_Utility.getArticle=1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2150882</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 5.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

If the password is not changed, remote users can access sensitive information about the device. Also, it's possible for configuration changes to be made, leading to a full compromise. CLVM-460662 
Apache Struts Jakarta Multipart parser Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (S2-045) 
2240 	443 	10.29.193.52	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 21:57 	S1 (Urgent) 	Apache Struts is a framework for building web applications. A vulnerability exists due to improper handling of requests with a malicious Content-Type value. If the Content-Type value isn't valid an exception is thrown which is then used to display an error message to a user.
Affected software:
Apache Struts 2.3.5 to 2.3.31
Apache Struts 2.5 to 2.5.10
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
The QID has two type of signatures. In the first type the scanner send a custom Content-Type header to check for command execution to the .action, .go,.do and other common files. In the second type the scanner asks the target to perform an arithmetic operation via the Content-Type header to check for command execution. Since this is an active check the scanner should be able to invoke the vulnerable struts configuration for the check to work.
Please note:
1) If there is an authentication scheme configured for the server, then VM scanner will not be able to detect this QID. In such cases we recommend using the WAS QID 150173 as WAS has support for authentication as well as in-dept crawling. Please refer to the Qualys Apache Struts blog:
<a href="https://blog.qualys.com/securitylabs/2017/03/14/apache-struts-cve-2017-5638-vulnerability-and-the-qualys-solution" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">https://blog.qualys.com/securitylabs/2017/03/14/apache-struts-cve-2017-5638-vulnerability-and-the-qualys-solution</a>
2) The requests sent by the scanner should be able to invoke the vulnerable struts configuration. If the vulnerable behavior is triggered in a nested directory which the scanner cannot find then this QID will not be posted.
QID detection logic (Authenticated):
Detection looks for "struts core" jar files in deployed web applications directories and lib folder of Tomcat server. Once it successfully finds the jar file, version information is extracted from that jar files and compared.
Please note: Our detection does not support if the applications are deployed with server configuration unpackWARs=false.	The vendor has released advisories and updates to fix these vulnerabilities. Refer to the following link for further details:
<a href="https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/Version+Notes+2.3.32" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Apache Struts 2.3.32</a>
<a href="https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/Version+Notes+2.5.10.1" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Apache Struts 2.5.10.1</a>
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/S2-045" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">S2-045</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

Exploiting the vulnerability could allow an authenticated VNC session to cause a stack overflow via a specific set of VNC packets. Successful exploitation of this issue could result in remote code execution in a virtual machine via the authenticated VNC session.

CLVM-460646 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.199.110	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 16:52 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460645 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.193.243	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 20:48 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460644 
VMware ESXi 6.5 Patch Release ESXi650-201712103-SG,ESXi650-201712101-SG Missing (KB 2151102)(Spectre) 
2240 		10.29.214.53	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 21:56 	S2 (High) 	VMware ESXi is an enterprise level computer virtualization product. 
The ESXi Host Client contains a vulnerability that may allow for stored cross-site scripting (XSS) (CVE-2017-4940)
CPU data cache timing can be abused to efficiently leak information out of mis-speculated CPU execution, leading to (at worst) arbitrary virtual memory read vulnerabilities across local security boundaries in various contexts. (Speculative execution is an automatic and inherent CPU performance optimization used in all modern processors.)(CVE-2017-5753, CVE-2017-5715)
QID Detection Logic(authenticated):
This QID checks for vulnerable versions of VMware ESXi 6.5	To resolve this issue, upgrade to VMware ESXi Build 7273056 or the latest VMware ESXi build. 
Refer to VMware advisory <a href="https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2151102" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">KB 2151102</a> for updates and build information.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2017-0021.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2017-0021: VMware ESXi 6.5</a>
<a href="https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2018-0002.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">VMSA-2018-0002: VMware ESXi 6.5</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460642 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.209.145	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 22:59 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460630 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.207.26	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 15:59 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460601 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.207.65	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 18:38 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460600 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.192.61	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 19:30 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460590 
Null Session/Password NetBIOS Access 
1367 		10.22.175.125	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 19:25 	S1 (Urgent) 	Unauthorized users can connect to this NetBIOS service without a password.	Null NetBIOS sessions can be disabled using the following methods:
Windows NT: 
1. Set the following registry key: 
HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa
Name: RestrictAnonymous
Type: REG_DWORD Value: 1
2. Restart your computer.
Windows 2000:
1. Start "Control Panel->Administrative Tools->Local Security Policy".
2. Open "Local Policies-->Security Options".
3. Make sure "Additional restrictions of anonymous connections" is set to
"No access without explicit anonymous permissions". 
4. Restart your computer.
Windows XP/2003: 
1. Start "Control Panel->Administrative Tools->Local Security Policy".
2. Open "Local Policies-->Security Options".
3. Make sure the following two policies are enabled:
•	Network Access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts 
•	Network Access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares
4. Disable Network Access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users.
5. Restart your computer. 
The above settings have no impact on domain controllers. If this vulnerability was discovered on a domain controller, please note that some of the recommended settings may not have any effect. Read the Microsoft article <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/kb/257988/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Description of Dcpromo Permissions Choices</a> for more information regarding Pre-Windows 2000 Compatible Access. Please read the Microsoft documents called <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;246261" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">How to Use the RestrictAnonymous Registry Value</a> for more information.
Samba: 
Make the following settings in smb.conf:
•	set "security" to "user" or "domain" or "server" as per your requirements. 
•	set "map_to_guest" to "Never" 
SECURITY = USER
This is the default security setting in Samba 2.2. With user-level security a client must first "log=on" with a valid username and password (which can be mapped using the username map parameter). Encrypted passwords can also be used in this security mode. Parameters such as user and guest only if set are then applied and may change the UNIX user to use on this connection, but only after the user has been successfully authenticated.
SECURITY = SERVER
In this mode Samba will try to validate the username/password by passing it to another SMB server, such as an NT box. If this fails it will revert to security = user, but note that if encrypted passwords have been negotiated then Samba cannot revert back to checking the UNIX password file, it must have a valid smbpasswd file to check users against. See the documentation file in the docs/ directory ENCRYPTION.txt for details on how to set this up.
SECURITY = DOMAIN
This mode will only work correctly if smbpasswd(8) has been used to add this machine into a Windows NT Domain. It expects the encrypted passwords parameter to be set to true. In this mode Samba will try to validate the username/password by passing it to a Windows NT Primary or Backup Domain Controller, in exactly the same way that a Windows NT Server would do.
•	Also add "restrict anonymous = 2" to the "[global]" configuration section.
Note:Setting this parameter in Samba versions prior to 4 may impact Samba's ability to service Windows 9x clients, act as a Domain Controller or serve as the Master Browser. 
For Windows Server 2008, please refer to <a href="http://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en-US/winservergen/thread/841523db-8c4b-43a0-9f28-be7270f92e2b" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Disable Server 2008 Null Sessions</a>.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460589 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.193.151	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 17:07 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460565 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	10.29.192.101	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 22:12 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460564 
IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication Remote Password Hash Retrieval Vulnerability 
2240 		10.29.198.163	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 17:15 	S2 (High) 	The IPMI 2.0 specification supports RMCP+ Authenticated Key-Exchange Protocol (RAKP) authentication, which allows remote attackers to obtain password hashes and conduct offline password guessing attacks by obtaining the HMAC from a RAKP message 2 response from a BMC.
Note: The IPMI 2.0 RAKP Authentication will be performed for the following users names: ADMIN, admin, root, Administrator, USERID.	IBM has made available a fix for CVE-2013-4037 at the following location: <a href="http://www-947.ibm.com/support/entry/portal/docdisplay?lndocid=MIGR-5093463" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">MIGR-5093463</a>
Workaround:
Ensure that no IPMI enabled devices are exposed to untrusted networks.
Set complex passwords.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460561 
Dropbear SSH Multiple Security Vulnerabilities 
2240 	22 	10.29.192.46	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 20:20 	S1 (Urgent) 	Dropbear is a software package that provides a Secure Shell-compatible server and client. It is designed as a replacement for standard OpenSSH for environments with low memory and processor resources, such as embedded systems.
Dropbear SSH contains the following vulnerabilites:
CVE-2016-7406: Format string vulnerability in Dropbear SSH allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via format string specifiers in the (1) username or (2) host argument.
CVE-2016-7407: The dropbearconvert command in Dropbear SSH allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted OpenSSH key file.
CVE-2016-7408: dbclient could run arbitrary code as the local dbclient user if particular -m or -c arguments are provided. This could be an issue where dbclient is used in scripts. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code within the context of an application using the affected library. 
CVE-2016-7409: The dbclient and server in Dropbear SSH before 2016.74, when compiled with DEBUG_TRACE, allows local users to read process memory via the -v argument, related to a failed remote ident. Dropbear SSH is prone to a remote information disclosure vulnerability. Successfully exploiting this issue will allow the attacker to gain sensitive information.
Affected Versions:
Dropbear SSH prior to 2016.74
QID Detection Logic (Authenticated):
This authenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of the Dropbear SSH client by running the "dropbear -V" command.
QID Detection Logic (Unauthenticated):
This unauthenticated detection matches vulnerable versions of Dropbear SSH based on the banner disclosed by the remote service.	Customers are advised to upgrade to <a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74</a> or later versions to remediate these vulnerabilities.
Patch:
Following are links for downloading patches to fix the vulnerabilities:
<a href="https://matt.ucc.asn.au/dropbear/" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Dropbear SSH 2016.74 or later</a>	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460551 
Cisco Router/Switch Default Password Vulnerability 
1367 	80 	10.22.168.31	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 15:25 	S1 (Urgent) 	Some Cisco routers/switches come with a default NULL password or unset password. If the password is not changed, remote users can access sensitive information about the device. Also, it's possible for configuration changes to be made, leading to a full compromise.	Please change your router/switch password immediately.
Check <a href="http://www.cisco.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">Cisco's Web site</a> for further information.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com 
CLVM-460549 
SSH User Login Bruteforced 
2240 	22 	10.29.192.218	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 20:37 	S1 (Urgent) 	One or more valid SSH user logins have been found through bruteforcing. 
An account on a router, firewall, or other network device has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0508)
A Unix account has a default, null, blank, or missing password.(CVE-1999-0502)
Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20 allows remote attackers to obtain administrative access by entering an unspecified password during a (1) SSH or (2) TELNET session.(CVE-2015-7755)
Affected Versions
This issue only affects ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20. No other Juniper products or versions of ScreenOS are affected by this issue.	Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.<P>
If the host is running Juniper ScreenOS 6.3.0r17 through 6.3.0r20, there are updates available from Juniper for <A HREF="https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=JSA10713" TARGET="_blank">CVE-2015-7755</A>. <P>
Workaround:<BR>
Restricting management access to only trusted management networks and hosts will help mitigate this issue. The attack can only be executed from a location where a legitimate management login would be permitted.
NOTE THAT THIS SOLUTION IS NOT SUGGESTING THAT YOU’RE RUNNING JUNOS, IT IS MERELY PROVIDING GUIDANCE ON WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE RUNNING JUNOS.
Change the user passwords so that they are difficult to guess.
Eg.. Strong passwords should (at a minimum) meet the following requirements:
	Contain at least eight alphanumeric characters. 
	Contain both upper and lower case letters. 
	Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9). 
	Contain at least one special character. 	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com

CLVM-460537 
SSH Protocol Version 1 Supported 
2240 	22 	10.29.212.190	2019.Feb.01 	2019.Feb.21 16:29 	S2 (High) 	SSH1 protocol was deprecated due to multiple vulnerabilities and design flaws.
Among multiple vulnerabilities that exist in SSH protocol Version 1 are:
a CRC32 compensation attack detector vulnerability (buffer overflow)
an unauthorized session key recovery problem
Multiple vendors' implementations are vulnerable due to the fact that these are protocol design errors. Version 2 of the SSH protocol fixed these errors.
Please refer to the following URL for more information:
<a href="http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/684820</a>	Disable SSH1 support. See your vendor's Web site for information on how to disable SSH protocol Version 1 support. Some references are provided below:
<a href="http://www.ssh.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">SSH Communications Security</a>
<a href="http://www.f-secure.com" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">F-Secure</a>
<a href="http://www.openssh.org" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">OpenSSH</a>
Note: Do not enable SSH Version 1 Fallback since systems with upgraded versions of SSH and with Fallback Version 1 enabled are still vulnerable.	rcanda@cisco.com 	tleese@cisco.com
